channel.title: Perl Weekly newsletter
channel.description: A free, once a week e-mail round-up of hand-picked news and articles about Perl.

item.title: Scrooge had it right! Perl role in Vienna
item.description: Our client is one of the largest product and price comparison platforms in German-speaking countries. With a website that allows consumers to compare deals on everything from toasters to tablets, our client helps their users hunt out the best values. This company is looking for someone who will deliver strong content and well-executed info to keep their users in the black.

item.title: What would your computer say about you? Perl, Python, NLP role in Amsterdam
item.description: Our client is the worldwide leader in machine intelligence for matching people with jobs, which is to say that when it comes to hiring, they know what they’re doing. They’re looking for a Natural Language Processing (NLP) Engineer who is passionate about Machine Intelligence and who has strong Perl and Python..

item.title: Forget the carrot and stick! Perl role in London
item.description: A titan of premium native advertising, our client dominates the field in sectors like tech, business, financial services, and lifestyle technology. As a company at the top of their game, they are looking for a Perl developer who is similarly eager to be the best. Required: Commercial experience with one of Mojolicious/Catalyst/Dancer and commercial experience with a front-end JavaScript framework.

item.title: Change the world without leaving your desk! Remote Perl role - UK, Switzerland or South Africa
item.description: Our client works with thousands of charities to provide cloud-based management tools to connect with their supporters. These gurus of giving are seeking a mid-level and a senior Perl developer to join their team. Both roles require excellent English communication skills, 4+ years of Perl experience, and experience with payment networks and systems.

item.title: A job with real flexibility. 100% remote Perl position
item.description: With the kind of flexibility yoga instructors only dream of, we have a job that offers Perl developers the freedom to work the way they want. Forget COVID isolation: this company was 100% remote long before the pandemic, and they have the tools to keep their team running smoothly. Looking for a Perl developer who has Mason, Moose, Mojolicious and experience with ticketing systems.

item.title: git branching strategy for when you cannot use the --force
NICEPERL's lists
item.description: Great CPAN modules released last week.

item.title: delete an element from a hash
Perl Weekly Challenge 132: Hash on the Mirror
item.description: As always, Roger not only discuss Perl/Raku solutions but also Transcript. I find it hard to follow, I must admit. Thanks for sharing.

item.title: Perl Weekly Challenge 132
item.description: I like the fact Luis make cool assumption and solve the task. I loved his analysis as always.

item.title: Perl Weekly Challenge 132: not so clear...
item.description: Luca showing off his Raku skill. Great work for anyone wants to learn Raku language. Thanks for sharing.

item.title: Perl Weekly Challenge 132: Mirror Dates and Hash Join
item.description: Laurent making good use of Raku power of dealing with dates. As bonus we also got Perl equivalent. Cool solutions.

item.title: Perl Weekly Challenge #132
item.description: James shed lights on the value of Hash Join. I wasn't aware of it before. Thanks for sharing.

item.title: PWC132 - Hash Join
item.description: Flavio shared the complexity aspect of the Hash Join task. It is something, I find very interesting. Thanks for sharing.

item.title: PWC132 - Mirror Dates
item.description: Flavio continued his fun with Raku and Perl showing the power of Date library is each language. Keep it up.

item.title: Dates(!) and Hashes(?) and Names, Oh My!!: The Weekly Challenge #132
item.description: Dave always have fun story to share every week. I really enjoy reading his blog. You don't want to miss it.

item.title: Mirrored Hash with Raku
item.description: Arne style of pictorial representation of the task is the highlight for me. Another interesting bit is you can get the debug information to understand the inner details. Keep up the great work.

item.title: Perl Weekly Challenge 132: Hash Join
item.description: Abigail discussed very interesting aspects of the task and it is worth taking a note. You don't want to miss out.

item.title: Perl Weekly Challenge 132: Mirror Dates
item.description: As always, Abigail, not just solved the task but also extended it to deal with other fun bits. Thanks for your contribution.

item.title: Perl Review - Perl Weekly Challenge - 130
item.description: Perl Solutions Review by Colin Crain.

item.title: RECAP - The Weekly Challenge - 132
item.description: Enjoy a quick recap of last week's contributions by Team PWC dealing with the "Mirror Dates" and "Hash Join" tasks in Perl and Raku. You will find plenty of solutions to keep you busy.

item.title: The Weekly Challenge - 133
item.description: Welcome to a new week with a couple of fun tasks "Integer Square Root" and "Smith Numbers". If you are new to the weekly challenge then why not join us and have fun every week. For more information, please read the FAQ.

item.title: Sub::Util
item.description: Flavio continued his research on Import related CPAN distribution.

item.title: XML::Twig
item.description: Work with XML file with ease as shown by Flavio in he blog.

item.title: Web::PageMeta
item.description: A mixed sync/async lazy Perl Moose HTTP-GET module

item.title: Fast Perl module installation with cpm
item.description: Mark sharing the details of cpm.

item.title: A pull request for Path::Tiny
item.description: Flavio talking about an issue related to Path::Tiny and his work around.

item.title: My Favorite Warnings: exiting
item.description: Tom discussing transfer of control out of normal flow. Interesting read.

item.title: Episodic Volunteering in FLOSS Communities
item.description: Ann is conducting research to understand episodic, or occasional, participation in the Perl / Raku community, in collaboration with The Perl Foundation.

item.title: #532 - Hacktoberfest 2021
item.description:
Hi there

Have you joined the annual Hacktoberfest 2021 run by Digital Ocean?

If not then you please join without any further delay. Hacktoberfest encourages participation in the open source community. You can earn a limited edition T-shirt by completing the challenge.

Not sure if you noticed, this time they have made an interesting change by allowing open source maintainers also to take part in the contest. Ever since I started The Weekly Challenge, I hardly found time to dedicate full time. Last year I could only submit 6 PR, enough to win the contest, since you only need to submit 4 PR. This year, I am only taking part as maintainer of open source project "The Weekly Challenge". The best year for me as contributor was year 2019 when I submitted 160 PR.

If you are looking for open source project to contribute then you can join "The Weekly Challenge" and win the competition by submitting 4 PRs in just one week.

How?

Well, you could submit 2 Perl and 2 Raku solutions to the weekly task. Just submit one solution per PR. I know it is cheating but a fair one in my humble opinion. Again, please don't limit yourself to just Perl and Raku. You are free to choose your favourite programming language. One more bit, please don't tie yourself to the current weekly challenge. You are free pick any past week challenges. Plenty of choices available. If you have any questions with regard to submit PR then please follow the blog post that explains every detail. If you still have any questions then please get in touch with me. You can find my details on the page. I am also accepting PR to the other open source project The Weekly Challenge website open source code.

If you are CPAN contributors then you could pick and choose your favourite distribution and contribute. However there is a catch, the distribution may or may not be part of the contest. Having said, you can contribute to my CPAN distributions if you fancy. I promise, I will make the distribution to be part of the contest so that your PR would count towards the target. Just yesterday, I received a Pull Request to one of my CPAN distribution, BankAccount::Validator::UK.

Happy Hacking !!!
